entry.title: Video: How religious are young Americans today?
entry.summary: Young adults today are less religious than older adults by traditional measures. But when it comes to spirituality, the differences are smaller. The post Video: How religious are young Americans today? appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 9 celestial events lighting up the night sky this June
entry.summary:
Whether you‚Äôre waking up early to spot Venus in the pre-dawn sky, staying up late to peep the Lagoon Nebula, or spending the whole night on the hunt for meteors, June‚Äôs night sky has something for every stargazer. Here‚Äôs what to keep an eye out for when you look up this month.
(9 must-see night sky events to look forward to in 2025.)
On June 1, Venus will reach its farthest distance west of the sun from the perspective of Earth‚Äîa point known as greatest western elongation. This is a particularly good time to get a glimpse at Earth‚Äôs neighboring planet, as it won‚Äôt be drowned out by sunlight.
In some time zones, the exact timing of this event occurs on May 31, while in others, it's on June 1. But the best time to view Venus is just before dawn, when it rises in the eastern ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Need to unwind? This new travel trend adds a twist.
entry.summary:
Taking action to restore and care for nature sparks the brain‚Äôs reward circuits, fostering a lasting sense of purpose and connection. Wellness-centric travel has long been popular, with numerous health studies touting the benefits of spending more time in nature. A new evolution of the trend puts wildlife at the center‚Äîresponsibly.
In today‚Äôs fast-paced and tech-dominated world, people are plugged into the conveniences of modern day life, but they‚Äôre as disconnected as ever, overlooking the simple joys of nature and the wellness benefits it can offer us. You could say that the more high-tech we become, the more nature we undoubtedly need. The practice of forest bathing to cultivate relaxation and ward off the effects of stress and anxiety is well-established, but next-level nature ‚Ä¶

entry.title: These are the best stargazing sites in North America
entry.summary:
Both urban and rural areas are darkening their skies to boost astrotourism. These dark sky sanctuaries, reserves, parks, and trails invite you to immerse yourself in the wonders of our night skies. Here‚Äôs where to go.
Travelers are increasingly lifting their eyes to nighttime skies in search of impressive celestial phenomena and, perhaps, more. ‚ÄúLooking up at the night sky is sort of what makes us human,‚Äù says Ruskin Hartley, the executive director of DarkSky International, a nonprofit group based in Tucson, Arizona. ‚ÄúWe have done it for millennia. Every single culture has told their first stories in the stars overhead, and they found meaning in the stars. Today, the vast majority of people are robbed of that.‚Äù
On a clear night last November, I spent over two hours in a dome a‚Ä¶

entry.title: Explore the UK through its family-friendly summer festivals
entry.summary:
Sewing camps and sensory gardens will be at this year‚Äôs Camp Bestival. Music festivals in the UK are doing more than ever to cater to all interests and ages. Here are this summer‚Äôs family-friendly highlights.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Music festivals are doing more than ever to cater to all interests and ages. Younger audiences are often won over purely by the fact that attendance typically involves camping, glamping or pitching up in a caravan ‚Äî an opportunity to sleep out in the wild. But the UK‚Äôs best festivals also provide an endless roster of activities, workshops and experiences to help families bond and create lasting memories. From chilled countryside escapes to adrenaline-sparking coastal adventures. Here are the golden tickets‚Ä¶

entry.title: The world‚Äôs plastic pollution crisis, explained
entry.summary:
Plastic trash drifts in the ocean in the Philippines. Much of the planet is swimming in discarded plastic, which is harming animal and possibly human health. Can plastic pollution be cleaned up?
Plastic pollution has become one of the most pressing environmental issues, thanks to the overwhelming rise in production of disposable plastic products.
Plastic pollution is most visible in developing Asian and African nations, where garbage collection systems are often inefficient or nonexistent. But the developed world, especially in countries with low recycling rates, also has trouble properly collecting discarded plastics.
Plastic trash has become so ubiquitous it has prompted efforts to write a global treaty negotiated by the United Nations.
Plastics made from fossil ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Pandemics to pollution: WHO Assembly delivers landmark health decisions
entry.summary: The 78th World Health Assembly concluded Tuesday in Geneva, marking several major milestones in global health. Delegates adopted the world‚Äôs first pandemic agreement and approved a significant boost in core funding for the World Health Organization (WHO).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan war exacerbates risk of cholera and malaria: UNICEF
entry.summary: The UN Children‚Äôs Fund (UNICEF) has warned of an escalating public health crisis in Sudan, as conflict and mass displacement continue to drive a surge in disease, particularly cholera and malaria.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Yemen: UN warns against Houthi-Israel escalation, calls for dialogue
entry.summary: The United Nations has called for restraint following another wave of escalation between Houthi rebels in Yemen and Israeli forces.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN awards 2025 Mandela Prize to Brenda Reynolds and Kennedy Odede
entry.summary: An Indigenous¬†social worker from Canada and a social entrepreneur from Kenya are the laureates of the 2025 Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela Prize, the United Nations announced on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòMy husband died in my arms‚Äô: Russian drone attacks on Ukrainians amount to crimes against humanity, UN investigators report
entry.summary: Russian drone attacks against civilians in the Kherson region of Ukraine constitute crimes against humanity and war crimes, independent UN human rights investigators concluded in a report published on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòWe are women like you‚Äô: UN honours peacekeepers for work in gender empowerment
entry.summary: In early summer 2024, Squadron Leader Sharon Mwinsote Syme of Ghana ventured into sector North of Abyei, a disputed region between Sudan and South Sudan where she was deployed as a military gender advocate with the UN Interim Security Force in Abyei (UNISFA).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Top UN envoy calls on Israel to end devastating strikes, starvation of civilians
entry.summary: Gaza‚Äôs population is being ‚Äústarved and denied the very basics,‚Äù while the region stands at a dangerous crossroads, the UN‚Äôs Middle East peace envoy warned the Security Council Wednesday, urging immediate action to halt the violence, restore aid and advance a two-State solution before time runs out.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN aid teams plead for access amid reports Gazans shot collecting food
entry.summary: In Gaza, dozens of Palestinians have been reportedly injured and shot trying to collect aid from the new US and Israeli-backed aid distribution facility operating independently of the UN.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Climate change: World likely to breach 1.5¬∞C limit in next five years
entry.summary: Fact: 2024 was the warmest year on record ‚Äì but the heat is far from over. A new report from the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) warns that global temperatures will likely continue rising, with an 80 per cent chance that at least one year between now and 2029 will be even hotter.

entry.title: How did this shark swim a record-breaking 4,000 miles?
entry.summary:
Bull sharks tend to be aggressive and live near shorelines, which has earned them fearsome reputations. One eight-foot-long female recently logged a record breaking 4,000-mile journey. Along her migration from Mozambique to Nigeria, the eight-foot-long female would have encountered a zone of water too cold to cross that has kept Africa's bull shark populations separated for 55,000 years.
When Turawa Hakeem caught a bull shark near Lagos, Nigeria last summer, the Ghanaian captain had no idea his crew was reeling a record winner onto his wooden fishing boat.
The eight-foot-long female had made an epic journey of at least 4,500 miles, the longest known movement of its species and the first time a bull shark was documented swimming through two oceans. The shark traveled from the M‚Ä¶

entry.title: Frozen shoulder is a real condition‚Äîand it mostly affects women
entry.summary:
Frozen shoulder is straightforward‚Äîthe condition means stiffness and difficulty in raising the arm. It can be caused by partial tears in the shoulder's tendon, as represented in this MRI scan. The painful affliction known as adhesive capsulitis can last for years‚Äîbut has long been ignored by medical researchers who doubted its existence. New treatments may finally promise a cure.
Stirrups, Pap smears, prenatal checks: At her busy office at Duke Women‚Äôs Health in Durham, NC, OB-GYN¬†Anne Ford‚Äôs work with female patients of all ages usually takes place from the waist down.
But Ford has noticed that a subset of her patients‚Äîall women entering or past menopause‚Äîcome to their appointments with a seemingly non-gynecological issue: adhesive capsulitis or ‚Äúfrozen shoulder,‚Äù a poorly un‚Ä¶

entry.title: These intimate safari camps offer a peek into Maasai culture
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
‚ÄúSimba!‚Äù The urgent whisper ‚Äî ‚Äòlion‚Äô in Swahili ‚Äî comes from Julius Naurori as he stands bolt upright in the back of our 4WD like a human antenna.
Immediately, our guide in the front slows the car to a cautious prowl and a hush descends, save for the tinkling silver discs tied to Julius‚Äôs waist as they sway in time with the rocking of the car. The dawn sky is still blushing crimson, and at first it‚Äôs hard to see what‚Äôs almost directly in front of us: four sleeping lions, their chocolate manes camouflaged as they lie on their sides in long, unruly grass marking the banks of the Mara River.
Our guide is Roca River Camp co-owner Ross Withey, and Julius, our wildlife-spotter, is his wingman on this safari drive in‚Ä¶

entry.title: These remote desert oases are Egypt‚Äôs hidden gems
entry.summary:
Siwa Oasis, a 12-hour drive from Cairo, is worth the trip to swim and float in hundreds of salt lakes and natural hot springs. Most visitors never experience the natural masterpieces that lie off the tourist trail‚Äîfrom bubbling hot springs to unearthly landscapes of dead volcanoes to the ‚ÄúValley of the Whales.‚Äù
The world knows Egypt for the Pyramids of Giza and cosmopolitan Cairo, the tourist-trodden temples of Luxor, and Red Sea resort towns. These coastal and Nile River Valley destinations are a narrow view of a country that‚Äôs 90 percent desert.
Few travelers venture into that 90 percent. The vast Western Desert, which blends into Libya and beyond, is Egypt‚Äôs great unknown. Adventurers since Alexander the Great have braved the harsh clime and been rewarded with the untouched‚Ä¶

entry.title: UN aims to transform urgency into action at Nice Ocean Conference
entry.summary: Countries are uniting in the French city of Nice next month to save the marine environment.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Exponential rise in synthetic drug production and trafficking in the Golden Triangle
entry.summary: The Golden Triangle ‚Äì the remote, jungle-covered border region where Thailand, Myanmar, and the Lao People‚Äôs Democratic Republic meet ‚Äì has seen an exponential surge in the illicit manufacture and trafficking of synthetic drugs.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sanctions relief for Syria offers ‚Äòpowerful message of hope,‚Äô says UN migration agency
entry.summary: The UN International Organization for Migration (IOM) has welcomed recent decisions by the United States, the United Kingdom and the European Union to ease sanctions against Syria.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan conflict triggers regional health crisis, warns WHO
entry.summary: As the war between rival militaries in Sudan continues, the World Health Organization (WHO) has raised alarm over the escalating health emergency, driven by ongoing violence, mass displacement, collapsing health systems and poor conditions inside refugee camps.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: New judge elected to the International Court of Justice
entry.summary: A seasoned diplomat and legal scholar from Jordan was elected on Tuesday to serve as a judge at the International Court of Justice (ICJ), the United Nations‚Äô principal judicial body.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Real cost of disasters is 10 times higher than previously thought, says UN
entry.summary: As countries face increasingly steep bills from natural hazards, the true cost of disasters is actually 10 times higher than previously estimated, with far-reaching effects across healthcare, housing, education and employment.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: UN agencies calls for aid ‚Äòsurge‚Äô as Israeli distribution plan begins
entry.summary: Reports indicated on Tuesday that Israel‚Äôs controversial aid distribution plan had begun in Gaza as the United Nations called once again on the Israeli authorities to allow an ‚Äúimmediate surge‚Äù in the amount of supplies reaching the enclave to prevent starvation.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Marketplace for government agencies to buy all the personal data about Americans
entry.summary: For the Intercept, Sam Biddle reports on government plans for a one-stop shop‚Ä¶ Tags: Intercept, privacy

entry.title: Undisclosed surveillance with facial recognition in New Orleans
entry.summary: For The Washington Post, Douglas MacMillan and Aaron Schaffer report on a system‚Ä¶ Tags: facial recognition, privacy, Washington Post

entry.title: 8 of the best beach cities in Spain
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
High-spirited northern surf hubs, relaxed Mediterranean-fronting neighbourhoods and glowing sands washed by the thundering Atlantic ‚Äî mainland Spain‚Äôs cities can offer all of this and more. Take your pick of these varied urban beauties, scattered around the country‚Äôs 3,000-mile peninsular coast. Beaches in Spain can get packed everywhere during the high season, from July to August, so for the best chance of solitude and space, it‚Äôs worth travelling in the quieter shoulder periods.
A pair of wide gold beaches, tucked into a crescent-moon bay between forested headlands, sets the scene for one of northern Spain‚Äôs most popular coastal escapes. Many San Sebasti√°n strolls begin on the promenade curving past Playa de On‚Ä¶

entry.title: Are airline loyalty schemes worth it?
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
When British Airways (BA) launched its revamped frequent-flyer scheme on 1 April, it probably didn‚Äôt anticipate the furore that would follow. The new logo and name change ‚Äî a contraction from the Executive Club to simply the Club ‚Äî were uncontroversial. Instead, the outcry concerned the airline changing the way it plans to reward its customers.
Like most airline loyalty schemes, BA rewards its customers with two sets of points. The first, reward points ‚Äî¬†known as Avios in BA‚Äôs case ‚Äî are essentially an airline currency, and you can save these over months or years and redeem them for cheap flights and upgrades. The second, loyalty points, which BA calls Tier points, are collected over a single year and will move you‚Ä¶

entry.title: UN rights mission deplores deadly Russian strikes in Ukraine
entry.summary: The UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission in Ukraine (HRMMU) has deplored a deadly wave of Russian missile and drone strikes that reportedly killed at least 13 civilians and injured 65 others, warning that the attack underscores the grave risks of using powerful explosive weapons in populated areas.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Explore New Zealand one scenic drive at a time
entry.summary:
Life moves at a slower pace in New Zealand so taking your time while hitting the wide-open road is the best way to experience it. Starting from the country‚Äôs main gateways, such as Auckland and Christchurch, these road trips offer the best chance to experience the wealth and breadth of New Zealand‚Äôs unparalleled landscapes.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
In Aotearoa (the MƒÅori name for New Zealand, which is often translated as ‚Äòthe land of the long white cloud‚Äô), life moves at a slower pace so taking your time while hitting the wide-open road is the best way to experience it. Meander through mountain ranges and past pancake rocks to wineries and whale-watching spots on New Zealand‚Äôs wild South Island, while on the North Island, take a leisur‚Ä¶

entry.title: Is Sasquatch real? Some Harrison Hot Springs residents say yes
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Henry Williams wasn‚Äôt always a believer in the Sasquatch. Growing up, he had of course heard the tales of old ‚Äî of a legendary hairy, bipedal primate said to roam the forests at sundown. Yet for much of his life, 76-year-old Henry had shrugged these stories off without much thought. They were used to remind youngsters to come home before nightfall, he‚Äôd reasoned. All that changed, however, on the day that the Sasquatch came to pay him a visit two decades ago, near his home in Squamish in southwest British Columbia.
‚ÄúIt threw a huge boulder into the middle of a nearby river,‚Äù says Henry, flinging his arms wide to imitate an almighty splash as we chat in the lobby of the Harrison Hot Springs Resort, a historic hotel ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Thousands flee homes in Mozambique as conflict and disasters fuel worsening crisis
entry.summary: More than 25,000 people have been forced to flee their homes in northern Mozambique in recent weeks, as conflict and a series of disasters fuel a worsening humanitarian crisis ‚Äì one that risks deepening as vital relief operations face a severe funding shortfall.

entry.title: 6 of the best rail adventures in British Columbia
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
British Columbia, Canada‚Äôs westernmost province, is well known for its spectacular landscapes, offering endless views of serrated peaks, opaline glacier lakes and feather-tipped pines. And what better way to take it all in than on a train, with those big-picture vistas slowly rolling by beyond the windowpanes ‚Äî here are some of the best rail routes to try.
Vancouver to Banff; 2 days This double-decker train is surely one of the world‚Äôs most scenic rail journeys, offering bubble-domed vistas of mountains, lakes, forests, gorges, rivers and glaciers and the chance to spot wildlife along the way. The classic First Passage to the West route follows part of the line from the historic Canadian Pacific Railway, Canada‚Äôs‚Ä¶

entry.title: Where to find Ireland's best food? Head west.
entry.summary:
Across County Cork‚Äôs wide and quiet expanse of gently rolling hills and craggy coastline, a culinary renaissance is unfolding, led by dairy farmers, foragers, fish smokers, and chefs. Here, Ireland‚Äôs soul and story are best understood on the plate.
Long overlooked on Europe‚Äôs gastronomic map, Ireland is emerging as a top culinary destination‚Äînowhere more so than in this rugged southwestern corner. County Cork's unique microclimate and creative community has served as fertile ground for culinary invention; and the hills are green nearly all year and shores are laden with seaweed superfoods. You‚Äôll find Michelin-starred restaurants hiding in villages of just a few hundred people, farmers crafting new kinds of cheese, and wild foragers bringing the native plants of Ireland back to palate‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why some people are better off sleeping on their sides
entry.summary:
If you struggle with sleep apnea, acid reflux, or back pain, changing how you sleep may offer some relief. Your sleep position can cause everything from back pain to acid reflux. A simple change can improve your health dramatically.
In recent years, a preponderance of research has shown that something as simple as sleeping on your side may be the answer to reducing back pain, heartburn, and sleep apnea‚Äîconditions that affect tens of millions of people‚Äîeven if it doesn‚Äôt also provide relief to some other issues people think it does.
‚ÄúSide sleeping does have clear benefits over stomach or back sleeping, but only for certain groups of individuals,"¬†says Raj Dasgupta, a pulmonary and sleep medicine physician at Huntington Memorial Hospital in California.
Here's what to know ‚Ä¶

entry.title: See Lake Como and the Italian Riviera without the crowds
entry.summary: Travelers looking for la dolce vita or the sweet life in Italy should consider a visit to the picturesque town of Menaggio on Lake Como. The three uniquely different towns of Rapallo, Varenna, and Menaggio offer elegant views, food tours and everything you need for your dream vacation. Most world travelers are familiar with the popular and often over-touristed cities in Italy such as Rome, Florence, Milan, and Naples, but there are lesser-known locales found on the Italian Riviera and in the Lake Como area that offer equally authentic experiences in Italian food, art, and cultural history. Here‚Äôs how to plan your dream Italian holiday to three towns in Northwest Italy‚Äîwithout the crowds. Situated on the coast of the Ligurian Sea just south of Genoa and north of Cinque‚Ä¶

entry.title: Quebec City offers the charm of Paris without the crowds
entry.summary:
Craving the romance of Paris without the jet lag or legions of other people? The City of Light welcomed nearly 30 million visitors in 2023, and even more admirers plan to travel there since the 2024 Summer Olympics and reopening of the Cathedral of Notre Dame. Canada‚Äôs Qu√©bec City, a UNESCO World Heritage Site with French roots, emanates European elegance yet welcomes about a fraction¬†of the visitors as Paris. Flights from the United States clock much shorter times too, providing travelers with Old World charm minus the travel fatigue. ¬†
French, British, and North American cultures weave together in this walkable, refined city. ‚ÄúQu√©bec City is French-speaking, but it‚Äôs North American, and it‚Äôs unique,‚Äù says David Mendel, an author and historian who has lived in Paris and has also resi‚Ä¶

entry.title: See Sally Ride‚Äôs boundary-breaking life in photos
entry.summary:
When pioneering female astronaut Sally Ride died of pancreatic cancer in 2012, a single line in her obituary told the story a lifetime of press coverage and fame had never revealed: her 27-year partnership with another woman, Tam O‚ÄôShaughnessy.
The revelation that Ride was a member of the LGBTQ+ community added another first to her lengthy list of historic accomplishments. She was not just the first American woman to go to space‚Äî41 years ago on June 18, 1983‚Äîbut the first known queer astronaut.
The revelation added a new dimension to the intense, brilliant physicist, loyal crew member, and passionate science education advocate. And it led some to question what Ride‚Äôs life may have been like in a less homophobic, sexist world. Ride‚Äôs private journey is uncovered in the award-winni‚Ä¶

Appendix: AI keywords used in this study
entry.summary: A webpage was classified as containing an AI mention if it had at least one of the following keywords. These keywords were detected using regular expression matching, included common variants and were not case sensitive, unless noted otherwise. The post Appendix: AI keywords used in this study appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The findings in this report are based on an analysis of the browsing behaviors of 900 U.S. adults who are members of the KnowledgePanel Digital online panel, a subset of Ipsos‚Äô KnowledgePanel. These panelists qualified for the study because they: After the March monitoring period, panelists‚Äô web browsing activity logs were delivered on April 7, [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: What Web Browsing Data Tells Us About How AI Appears Online
entry.summary: One month of web browsing data shows most respondents visited a search page with an AI-generated summary, but visits to in-depth content about AI were much rarer. The post What Web Browsing Data Tells Us About How AI Appears Online appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Why cancer rates are rising in young women‚Äîand what to do about it
entry.summary:
A PET scan of a female patient with breast cancer, which has spread to the lymph nodes, bones and liver. A recent report found that women account for two-thirds of all cancers diagnosed in people under 50. But it's not all bad news.
In its recent annual report, the American Cancer Society shared some striking news: Cancer is turning up more frequently in young people ‚Äì especially in young women.¬†
Before we panic: The trend is not entirely a new one. Women have long had higher cancer rates than men in younger age groups. And there‚Äôs good news in the report too, says Otis Brawley, an oncologist and epidemiology professor at Johns Hopkins University‚Äôs Bloomberg School of Public Health. Namely, it found that, overall, cancer deaths have been trending downward.
But the report‚Ä¶

entry.title: Been to Barcelona? Now try Spain's lesser-known cities
entry.summary:
Stay a few days to roam the sloping Albaic√≠n district, where locals and visitors gather on broad terraces to catch views across terracotta rooftops to the Alhambra, backed by the spectacular Sierra Nevada mountains. Watch flamenco, roam medieval streets and find local tapas haunts in these destination dupes.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
With Spain receiving record-breaking numbers of international visitors in the past two years ‚Äî up to 94 million last year ‚Äî it pays to hunt out its quiet corners. And there are plenty of areas where travellers have yet to claim a stake. While major Spanish cities like Barcelona, Madrid and Seville justifiably receive millions of visitors a year, the country is packed with dozens of disarmingly beautiful and‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why Tateyama Kurobe route is Japan‚Äôs ultimate mountain journey
entry.summary:
The journey on Tateyama Kurobe Alpine Route involves travelling by train, bus, funicular, cable car and even a short stretch on foot. This multimodal route through the country‚Äôs Northern Alps is a great alternative to the similar journey around Mount Fuji ‚Äî and one which attracts far fewer visitors.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
For travellers looking to explore the peaks of Japan, it doesn‚Äôt get much better than the Tateyama Kurobe Alpine Route, an extraordinary expedition through the country‚Äôs Northern Alps in the centre of the main island of Honshu. Like a similar but far more travelled route around Mount Fuji to the south,¬†this itinerary incorporates multiple forms of transport ‚Äî a train, funicular, highland bus, cable car and electric ‚Ä¶

entry.title: How one young pharaoh turned Egypt into a superpower
entry.summary:
The death of Queen Hatshepsut opened the door to rebellion in the Levant. After 22 years in power, she disappeared from history and Thutmose III occupied the throne of Egypt alone. A coalition of Canaanite city-states, supported by the Mitanni Empire and rulers of Kadesh, began to rebel against the new pharaoh. It would come to a head in the walled city of Megiddo, in what today is Israel. Sited on the Plain of Esdraelon, the city could control two trade routes of special interest: one connecting with the coastline and the other leading north to Kadesh. As this was Thutmose‚Äôs first military campaign, the pressure on him was considerable.
According to the large propaganda inscription on the walls of Akh Menu (the Temple of Thutmose III at Karnak), the young pharaoh gathered his m‚Ä¶

entry.title: UNHCR underscores plight of Rohingya refugees amid alarming reports
entry.summary: The UN refugee agency (UNHCR) on Friday released a¬†statement expressing grave concern over reports that two boats carrying Rohingya refugees sank off the coast of Myanmar earlier this month, with an estimated 427 people dead.

entry.title: Diplomats prepare ground for June conference on two-State solution for Israel and Palestine
entry.summary: Diplomats convened at UN Headquarters in New York on Friday to lay the groundwork for a crucial international conference in June, aimed at advancing global efforts towards achieving a two-State solution to the Israel-Palestine conflict.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Escalating violence drives food crisis across eastern DR Congo, warns WFP
entry.summary: As violence intensifies in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), the World Food Programme (WFP)¬†warned Friday that food insecurity is worsening both within the country and in neighbouring States, where 140,000 Congolese have fled since January.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN rights chief calls on South Sudan‚Äôs warring parties to end renewed fighting
entry.summary: The UN on Friday warned of further deterioration in the human rights situation in South Sudan amid an uptick in hostilities, arbitrary arrests and hate speech since February.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Guterres calls on Israel to accept UN‚Äôs ‚Äòdetailed, principled‚Äô aid plan for Gaza
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General on Friday outlined a five-stage plan to provide lifesaving aid to the stricken population of Gaza, making clear the organization will not take part in any scheme that fails to respect international law or basic humanitarian principles.

entry.title: Syrians face staggering needs amid insecurity and healthcare crisis
entry.summary: Millions of people in Syria continue to face mortal danger from unexploded munitions, disease and malnutrition and more international support is urgently required, senior UN aid officials said on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Aid teams highlight growing anxiety in Gaza after food is looted
entry.summary: Long-awaited food supplies have been looted in Gaza overnight while being transported to desperate communities in the war-torn enclave, UN aid teams reported on Friday.

entry.title: In search of ‚Äòfjaka‚Äô‚Äîthe Croatian art of doing nothing
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
This story begins ‚Äî as many good yarns do ‚Äî in a bar. Specifically, Beach Bar Dodo beside Dubrovnik‚Äôs seafront, where I‚Äôm sipping beer with a friend. David Farley had sub-let his perfectly nice flat in New York to decamp to Croatia. What‚Äôs he doing with his days, I ask. Not much, he replies: ‚ÄúPerfecting my fjaka.‚Äù
Fjaka, pronounced ‚Äòfee-aka‚Äô, could only have come from a land of sunbaked islands. It is, David explains, no place to go, no place to be. Allowing days to drift and blur. Back in the capital, Zagreb, they make rude jokes about Dalmatians as donkeys, but that misses the point entirely. With fjaka, the region has elevated easy living into an artform.
With no better plans, I decide to embark on a quixot‚Ä¶

entry.title: Going to the beach is good for your brain, according to science
entry.summary:
There's little more relaxing than spending time at the beach‚Äîbut what's going on in your brain during a day spent playing in the waves? Scientists are discovering more of the benefits of "blue spaces" like the coast. Visiting the coast can help you relieve stress and get more active‚Äîand it may even change the way you cope with pain.
The coast has long been a place of healing. In 18th-century Europe, doctors prescribed beach time for ailments ranging from tuberculosis to leprosy. Patients spent their days bathing in (and often drinking) mineral-rich sea water, and at night, they fell asleep to the sounds of briny winds and crashing waves.
While elements of this early sea therapy have since been disproven, modern science continues to find that nature is good for us. Researchers ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Do dolphins have a language? Scientists are finding new clues.
entry.summary:
Bottlenose dolphins living near Sarasota, Florida have been observed making consistently structured whistles that suggest a common meaning. ‚ÄúIf there is a species that we might be able to engage with in some kind of two-way communication, these guys are really good candidates.‚Äù
Dolphins are some of the most vocal animals in our oceans. Their pods are a bustling soundscape of clicks, whistles, and buzzy pulses. What to our ears is a creaking door or a melodic pop is to a dolphin a means to echolocate or communicate.
They even have names‚Äîresearch has found they use ‚Äòsignature whistles‚Äô to identify themselves, a sort of vocal version of a human‚Äôs signature. These whistles are produced by one individual and repeated by another‚Äî‚ÄúJeff, Jeff‚Äù‚Äîto initiate or re-establish contact. The ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Uncovering Williamsburg and the Historic Triangle
entry.summary:
The clang of a blacksmith at work, historical reenactments and tours, beautiful scenic drives, and outdoor adventure‚Äîthere‚Äôs nothing quite like Williamsburg, Virginia, no matter the season.¬†
History is present and alive in the rhythm of the Historic Triangle: Colonial Williamsburg, Jamestown, and Yorktown. National Geographic Photographer Greg Kahn recently traveled to this all-American region to capture this experience through the quiet, sensory details that shape memory: the clack of a horse's hoof, the flicker of firelight in a blacksmith‚Äôs shop, the lap of a wave as it hits a sandy shore. It's all here in Williamsburg. undefined undefined undefined undefined In Colonial Williamsburg, the Fifes and Drums Corps preserves the powerful rhythms of 18th-century mili‚Ä¶

entry.title: Do fish sleep? Here‚Äôs what scientists have discovered so far
entry.summary:
A protective mucous cocoon surrounds this parrotfish as it sleeps in Australia's Great Barrier Reef. This layer of protection helps fend off predators so parrotfish can get a good night's rest. Sleep in fish may look different from humans, but rest is essential for survival. Here‚Äôs what experts have to say about fish sleep.
  If you‚Äôve ever gone snorkeling on a coral reef during the day, you likely saw waves of brightly colored fish of all shapes and sizes. But return to the same spot in the middle of the night, and most of those same creatures will have vanished.¬† Which might make one wonder, do fish¬†sleep¬†? ‚Ä¶

entry.title: 10 of the best hotels in Prague
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
It might be the medieval architecture or the riverside setting, the youthful atmosphere or ‚Äî arguably ‚Äî the world‚Äôs best beer. Whatever the reason, the Czech capital is a perennial favourite. The good news is that the shortfall in rooms of a decade ago is no longer an issue. Plenty of new hotels have opened, standards have risen and prices have moderated. Properties in the central Old Town feature historic settings and period details. For an authentic local feel, consider one of Prague‚Äôs residential quarters, like elegant Vinohrady or artsy Hole≈°ovice. Wherever you decide to stay, efficient public transport is always close at hand to whisk you about.
Best for: fashionistas The long-awaited reopening of the ar‚Ä¶

entry.title: World News in Brief: UK cedes sovereignty over Chagos Islands, suffering in Sudan deepens, UN releases new emergency relief funds
entry.summary: The United Kingdom agreed to cede its control over the Chagos Islands to the Republic of Mauritius in an agreement signed between the two countries on Thursday.

entry.title: Civilians ‚Äòtrapped and terrorised‚Äô: UN sounds alarm over collapse of critical protections
entry.summary: With more than 36,000 civilian deaths recorded in conflict zones in 2024 and sexual violence surging, senior UN officials warn that the international framework designed to protect civilians is collapsing.

entry.title: Gaza: Strikes on houses and tents responsible for over half of deaths this week
entry.summary: More than half the people killed in Gaza over the past week were in shelters and residential buildings, the UN human rights office OHCHR said on Thursday.

entry.title: Kenya: Refugees facing ‚Äòlowest ever‚Äô emergency food rations amid funding crisis
entry.summary: The UN World Food Programme (WFP) warned on Thursday that it has been forced to cut food aid to unprecedented lows in Kenya‚Äôs sprawling refugee camps, as a result of severe funding shortages.

entry.title: Guterres strongly condemns killing of Israeli diplomats in US capital
entry.summary: UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres has strongly condemned the ‚Äúappalling killing‚Äù of two Israeli embassy officials in the United States capital, stressing that ‚Äúnothing can justify such a horrific act,‚Äù his Spokesperson said in a statement on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: SECURITY COUNCIL LIVE: Ambassadors debate safety of civilians with 36,000 lives lost during conflict last year
entry.summary: We're live as the Security Council convenes for its annual open debate on the protection of civilians in armed conflict, with briefings from UN relief chief Tom Fletcher and the head of UN Women Sima Bahous. Ambassadors will discuss evolving threats, including use of heavy weapons and the rise of lethal autonomous killing machines such as drones. The UN has documented a spike in deaths, with Gaza, Lebanon, Myanmar, Sudan and Ukraine among the hardest-hit. Mobile app users can follow here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: All eyes on Gaza as aid teams retrieve first lifesaving relief in months
entry.summary: UN agencies in Gaza confirmed on Thursday that desperately needed aid has finally arrived at warehouses inside the enclave after an 11-week blockade by Israeli authorities.

entry.title: How to plan the ultimate Trans-Canadian Highway road trip
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Stretching from coast to coast, the Trans-Canada Highway is a ribbon of road that stitches together the vast landscapes of Canada, from the glacier lakes of Alberta to the prairies of Manitoba. But it‚Äôs the British Columbia section that arguably shines brightest, offering a wealth of experiences across some 500 miles.
The real charm of driving this route is watching the scenery beyond the windscreen switch from lush rainforest to the rugged Rocky Mountains. Take your time: six days is ideal, pausing to uncover the mysteries of old ghost towns, delve into the region‚Äôs Chinese heritage, or experience the thrill of whitewater rafting. Each stop offers a new perspective on Canada‚Äôs wild western frontier.
The adv‚Ä¶

entry.title: Anatomy of an Ecocide: The Mysterious Poisoning of Czechia‚Äôs Becva River
entry.summary: Our investigation found that a factory owned by a former Czech prime minister should have been the prime suspect in an environmental disaster. But authorities looked elsewhere.

entry.title: Here's what to do if your flight is delayed or canceled in the U.S.
entry.summary:
Air travel can be a stressful experience, especially if your flight has been delayed or canceled. Travel experts provide ways to reduce your anxiety if you‚Äôre stranded in a U.S. airport. From getting a refund to rebooking your trip, here‚Äôs what to know about handling air travel curveballs‚Äîand your rights as a traveler.
In a perfect world, every flight would take off promptly and make it to its final destination 20 minutes early. But in the real world, delays and outright cancellations are all too common. From thunderstorms to mechanical issues to air traffic control snafus, there are plenty of reasons to prevent your plane from making an on-time departure. The good news is that travelers have options and access to some compensation when wait times drag on. Here‚Äôs what to know when ‚Ä¶

entry.title: How do clownfish survive a heat wave?
entry.summary:
As she checked the measurements again, Ph.D. student Melissa Versteeg was worried something was wrong with her figures. The fish seemed to be shrinking.¬†
‚ÄúShe was measuring them three times,‚Äù says Theresa Rueger, a marine biologist who worked with Versteeg at Newcastle University in England. ‚ÄúShe had several people measuring them at the same time to really make sure that we're confident with the numbers.‚Äù¬†
But the measurements were correct. Versteeg‚Äôs data showed that the individual clown anemonefish (Amphiprion percula) were actually getting shorter during a marine heat wave.
The findings‚Äîpublished in the journal Science Advances‚Äîmark the first ever observations of a coral reef fish shrinking because of environmental stressors. Scientists have noticed some fish shrinking at‚Ä¶

entry.title: This Spanish dining tradition is one of its best-kept secrets
entry.summary:
The fixed menu, which typically costs between 10 and 16 euros depending on where you're dining, includes a starter, main course, and dessert. One of Spain‚Äôs most beloved lunch traditions is also one of the best ways to get an authentic, budget-friendly meal here‚Äîbut most visitors have never heard of it.
It‚Äôs easy to spot when lunch has arrived in Spain. Shops, businesses, and schools shut their doors. Crowds begin to gather, spilling onto sidewalks, and packing into bars and restaurants in search of a good meal. While most visitors flock to the nearest plaza patio drawn in by signs for paella and sangria, most locals are settling into their favorite restaurants for one of Spain‚Äôs most beloved food traditions‚Äîmen√∫ del d√≠a.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 158 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Center‚Äôs nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from Oct. 21 to 27, 2024. A total of 9,593 panelists responded out of 10,612 who were sampled, for [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 30% of Americans Consult Astrology, Tarot Cards or Fortune Tellers
entry.summary: Most who use astrology (or a horoscope), tarot cards or a fortune teller say they do so just for fun rather than for insights about life. The post 30% of Americans Consult Astrology, Tarot Cards or Fortune Tellers appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Biodiversity loss demands urgent global action, says UN chief
entry.summary: UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres has called on countries to radically rethink their relationship with nature, warning that biodiversity loss is a global crisis no nation can ignore.

entry.title: Haiti: Displaced children face sexual violence risk
entry.summary: Armed violence and insecurity in Haiti have exposed already vulnerable children to sexual violence and exploitation, the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) warned on Wednesday.

entry.summary: An ‚Äúhorrific‚Äù attack on a school bus in Pakistan‚Äôs Baluchistan Province on Wednesday which left six dead ‚Äì including four children ‚Äì has been condemned by the UN children‚Äôs agency.

entry.summary: Football unites fans worldwide ‚Äì but on Wednesday it matched the sport‚Äôs global reach with the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). In the lead-up to¬†World Football Day, marked on 25 May.

entry.summary: Noor, a 16-month-old toddler, is from the Lahj governorate in the southwest corner of Yemen. A UN-partner volunteer diagnosed her with severe malnutrition ‚Äì and her story became headline news when the UN relief chief recounted it to the Security Council during an impassioned briefing last week.

entry.summary: Southeast Asian nations should do more to protect people from being reeled into scam farms, top independent human rights experts said on Wednesday.

entry.title: Gaza: Aid trucks still waiting for Israeli green light inside enclave
entry.summary: UN aid workers said on Wednesday that they are still waiting for permission from Israel to distribute five trucks‚Äô worth of lifesaving relief that was allowed into Gaza at the start of the week, after an 11-week blockade.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Explore the Pantanal, Brazil's jaguar country, in photos
entry.summary: This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK). Encounters with pantaneiros (local cattle herders) are common as they cross wooden bridges, essential for navigating the flooded landscape during wet season. While ranching has long coexisted with the region‚Äôs biodiversity, intensive livestock production and infrastructure development threaten the delicate balance. entry.title: 5 Free Open Source Digital Tools to Combat Disinformation

entry.title: These London landmarks star in Hollywood's biggest spy movies
entry.summary: The headquarters of the British Secret Intelligence Service (SIS or MI6) at Vauxhall Cross is just one of the star attractions featured in spy TV shows and movies, including Mission: Impossible‚ÄîThe Final Reckoning. From Dr. No to Mission: Impossible ‚Äî The Final Reckoning, here‚Äôs where Hollywood‚Äôs greatest spies left their mark on the British capital. London¬†has been a favorite operational theater for cinematic espionage for nearly a century.¬†¬†The capers began with Alfred Hitchcock, who established the modern spy thriller with¬†The 39 Steps¬†in 1935, using¬†King's Cross Station. On May 23, this tradition continues when filmgoers can catch Tom Cruise as super spy Ethan Hunt in¬†Mission: Impossible ‚Äì The Final Reckoning, with the city serving as the plo‚Ä¶

entry.title: This generation is facing a host of totally unique health threats
entry.summary:
A child in Paris watches a screen on February 14, 2024. Four ways the world has profoundly changed for today's young people, according to a comprehensive new global report.
Adolescence can be rife with anxieties and challenges, but today‚Äôs youth face unique threats on a scale encountered by no previous generation, according to an exhaustive new report on their health and wellbeing.
More than one billion people aged 10 to 24 are at risk of poor health outcomes by 2030, which is at least half the global adolescent population, concluded the report published on Tuesday in the Lancet, a leading medical journal. Adolescents are experiencing rising rates of obesity and mental health struggles, while also grappling with the influence of digital technologies and a destabilized global c‚Ä¶

entry.title: This deadly prehistoric wasp captured prey with 'Venus flytrap' abs
entry.summary:
The 99-million-year-old fossil was preserved in amber and uncovered in Myanmar. This one-of-a-kind predatory strategy has never been seen in other insects. Scientists think it was used to trap flies into incubating the wasp‚Äôs eggs.
In Greek mythology, the sea monster Charybdis swallowed and regurgitated large volumes of water, creating whirlpools powerful enough to drag passing ships to their doom. Ninety-nine million years before the myth was created, in the mid-Cretaceous, the wasp Sirenobethylus charybdis deployed a similar deadly trap that recently earned it a scientific name inspired by the mythological monster.
A Venus flytrap-like structure on the wasp‚Äôs abdomen held captives in place as the wasp deposited its eggs into its victim, forcing it to incubate its offspring.‚Ä¶

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 167 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Center‚Äôs nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from April 7 to April 13, 2025. A total of 3,589 panelists responded out of 4,036 who were sampled, [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Views of how much discrimination transgender people, gay and lesbian people, women and men face in the U.S.
entry.summary: Nearly eight-in-ten Americans (77%) say there is a lot of (48%) or some (30%) discrimination against transgender people in society. And seven-in-ten Americans say there is a lot of or some discrimination in society against people who are gay or lesbian. Read the overview of this report for Americans‚Äô views of all 20 groups asked [‚Ä¶] The post 3. Views of how much discrimination transgender people, gay and lesbian people, women and men face in the U.S. appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Views of how much discrimination Muslims, Jews, evangelicals and atheists face
entry.summary: Compared with last year, perceptions of discrimination against Jews and Muslims have declined among both Republicans and Democrats (including independents who lean toward each party). There also has been a modest decrease in the share of the public saying evangelical Christians face at least some discrimination, largely due to a change among Republicans. Read the [‚Ä¶] The post 2. Views of how much discrimination Muslims, Jews, evangelicals and atheists face appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Views of how much discrimination racial and ethnic groups in the U.S. face
entry.summary: Most Americans say there is at least some discrimination against Black, Hispanic and Asian people, while fewer than half say White people experience a lot of or some discrimination. These attitudes differ considerably across racial and ethnic groups. Read the overview of this report for Americans‚Äô views of all 20 groups asked about on the [‚Ä¶] The post 1. Views of how much discrimination racial and ethnic groups in the U.S. face appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: How Much Discrimination Do Americans Say Groups Face in the U.S.?
entry.summary: Republicans are less likely than in 2024 to say there is discrimination against Black, Hispanic, Asian and White people. The post How Much Discrimination Do Americans Say Groups Face in the U.S.? appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.summary: Land is sinking, or subsiding, at a slow rate of millimeters per year.‚Ä¶ Tags: land, sinking, Washington Post

entry.title: A taste of New York's Hudson Valley
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
I pull up at Orange County Distillery‚Äôs 100-year-old barn, around an hour‚Äôs drive from New York City, as chef Anthony Mario Acevedo is busy preparing pork belly on an outdoor grill. It‚Äôs a tempting scent, but before we eat, the distillery‚Äôs co-owner John Glebocki is keen to show me the surrounding estate at Brown Barn Farms. Within two minutes, aboard a farm buggy, we‚Äôre out into a freshly ploughed field with soil that‚Äôs almost charcoal-black.
This 26,000-acre swathe of land, known as the Black Dirt Region, is a protected area containing some of the world‚Äôs most fertile soil. It covers much of the southern part of New York state‚Äôs Orange County, from the Hudson River at its eastern edge into parts of neighbouring‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why the future of fashion is ‚Äòfarm to closet‚Äô
entry.summary:
On a damp December¬†morning in the mountainous district of Ambarawa in Central Java, a woman in an inky black sleeveless vest and gathered skirt balances herself on the back of a motorbike that carries her through a small village, past houses adorned with tropical plants and birdcages, and into a forest. The land here, some 300 miles east of Indonesia‚Äôs capital of Jakarta, brims with shrubs and trees that grow a variety of crops, including cassava and coffee. But it‚Äôs the forest floor that‚Äôs brought Denica Riadini-Flesch, 34, to this corner of her home country. Under the shade of banana, papaya, and coconut trees, she‚Äôs trying to seed a revolution‚Äîin the form of hundreds of vibrant indigo plants, all casting a glossy viridescence across the soil.
Riadini-Flesch is the founder of Su‚Ä¶

entry.summary: After three years of negotiations sparked by the COVID-19 crisis, countries have adopted the world‚Äôs first-ever international agreement to better prevent, prepare for, and respond to future pandemics. The new accord marks a major step towards ensuring stronger global cooperation to protect lives and avoid the devastating consequences of future outbreaks.

entry.title: 7 of the best new museums to visit this year
entry.summary:
Saka Museum in Bali shines a light on often-overlooked aspects of Balinese culture. From the world‚Äôs largest archaeological space dedicated to a single civilisation to a fascinating deep dive into regional BBQ, these new museums are worthy of your attention in 2025. Here‚Äôs where to visit this year.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
Whether it‚Äôs getting in touch with different cultures, finding creative inspiration or even sinking your teeth into the history of a specific subject, museums can be intimate and interactive spaces that conjure new trains of thought while transporting visitors into other worlds ‚Äî even if just for a brief moment. And 2025 is a great year to wander collection-filled halls, get lost in exhibitions and stimulate the sens‚Ä¶

entry.title: 3 of Mexico‚Äôs lesser-known archaeological wonders
entry.summary:
The Temple of the Inscriptions at the ruins of the Maya city of Palenque, in Chiapas, Mexico. For those seeking a quieter, more affordable alternative to Chich√©n Itz√°, these temples across the Yucat√°n Peninsula offer a glimpse into the rich history of the Maya.
Nestled in the jungles of the Yucat√°n, about 45 minutes from Valladolid, lies one of Mexico‚Äôs most visited archaeological sites‚ÄîChich√©n Itz√°. Once a thriving Maya city with an estimated 35,000 residents, it now draws crowds of visitors from around the world to admire its grand temples and explore the region‚Äôs rich history.
Designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1988 and later named one of the New Seven Wonders of the World, Chich√©n Itz√° continues to break visitation records. While its significance and beauty is unde‚Ä¶

entry.title: There‚Äôs more to the French Riviera than Nice or Cannes
entry.summary:
On the French Riviera, La Turbie is just one of several lesser-known cities and villages that tourists should consider visiting on the French Riviera. Add the ancient Roman Trophy of Augustus monument to your trip itinerary in La Turbie. While tourists flock to magnetic destinations like Nice and Cannes, these often overlooked small towns offer art, history, and natural beauty‚Äîwithout the crowds.
Quiet, unspoiled, and often overlooked ‚Äî welcome to the softer side of the French Riviera. Vence carries the artistic legacy of Matisse and Chagall. La Turbie still bears the weight of Roman ambition, its ancient monument towering over the landscape. And in Roquebrune-Cap-Martin, modernist visions and medieval myths share the same sun-drenched cliffs.
(Related: The pearl of the French‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why this over-the-counter drug may not be worth the risk
entry.summary:
Diphenhydramine, a common antihistamine found in over-the-counter allergy and sleeping medications, may increase users' risk for dementia when taken daily over a prolonged period. Experts say the drug can also be harmful if taken in large doses beyond its recommended use. Diphenhydramine is the active ingredient in countless over-the-counter medications. But experts say there are serious risks to taking too much of the drug‚Äîor taking it too long.
If you‚Äôre among the one in three adults who struggles with seasonal allergies, the one in 10 dealing with some form of insomnia, or are among the millions dealing with the occasional cold or cough, chances are you‚Äôve got drugs containing diphenhydramine in your medicine cabinet. But what you may not realize is that for years doctors have b‚Ä¶

entry.title: Prostate problems are common as you age. Here‚Äôs what to know.
entry.summary:
Many men keep quiet about their prostate problems, but ignoring the ubiquitous health issue won‚Äôt make it go away.
About one of every eight males will be diagnosed with prostate cancer in their lives, and half of all those between 51 and 60 years old will suffer from a benign enlarged prostate. That number climbs to 70 percent among men ages 60 to 69, and 90 percent among men over 85.
Arvin George, director of the Johns Hopkins Medicine prostate cancer program, says experts don‚Äôt know the exact mix of genetic, environmental, dietary, or other factors that play a role in prostate problems as men age. That means there‚Äôs no easy path to avoid them. ‚ÄúFor both an enlarged prostate and prostate cancer, there‚Äôs no ‚Äòapple a day‚Äô to prevent this,‚Äù he says.
Fortunately, there are ways‚Ä¶

entry.title: Bhutan‚Äôs beauty beckons tourists. Here‚Äôs how to plan your trip.
entry.summary:
Built on a sheer cliff, Paro Taktsang is also known as the Tiger's Nest Monastery. There‚Äôs no bad time to visit this Himalayan kingdom, which has excellent hikes year-round and vibrant cultural festivals every month. Here‚Äôs how to experience it all.
Considered by some to be the real-life location of the elusive Shangri La, Bhutan is a small Himalayan enclave that also happens to be the last remaining Buddhist Kingdom in the world. Here, there are many more Buddhist temples and monasteries than days of the year, and just about as many festivals.
Add in rolling hills, dense forests, and countless never-to-be-named mountains in areas so remote that it takes a week‚Äôs worth of hiking to reach the nearest village, and you have yourself a culture-loving trekker‚Äôs dream. From two-mile‚Ä¶

entry.title: These capuchins are abducting babies from howler monkeys‚Äîfor fun?
entry.summary:
Here a white-faced capuchin monkey perches on a tree branch in Manuel Antonio National Park in Costa Rica. A group from the same genus has been observed with stolen howler monkey babies on a small island off the coast of Panama.  A young male nicknamed Joker was probably the first to start carrying a howler monkey baby on his back for days on end. Then a group of other young males started to copy him.
On a tiny island off the coast of Panama called Jicar√≥n, a male capuchin monkey called Joker appears to have started a disturbing trend.
Camera traps caught Joker, nicknamed for the scar on his face, and other male white-faced capuchins (Cebus capucinus imitator) carrying kidnapped howler monkey infants on their backs. Researchers originally set up the traps in 2017 after a ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why this small US city packs a big culinary punch
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
‚ÄúOyster farming used to be really male dominated,‚Äù says Amy Gaiero. ‚ÄúBut that‚Äôs starting to change. I‚Äôm noticing more women out here working on the water.‚Äù The morning air is still so crisp that her words produce a cloud of mist over the shiny aluminium barge as we chug towards Nauti Sisters Sea Farm: a small but mighty micro-oyster venture where Amy and her sisters Alicia and Chelsea cultivate shellfish destined for Portland‚Äôs white-tablecloth restaurants.
Fresh out of college, Amy isn‚Äôt your typical marine farmer: she‚Äôs young, female, sporting on-trend outdoorsy gear and ‚Äî ironically ‚Äî is allergic to shellfish. Yet, reeled in by the promise of harvesting low-impact, hyper-local food, the plucky fisherwoman has fo‚Ä¶

entry.title: Drone strikes on civilian infrastructure in Port Sudan must end: UN expert
entry.summary: Repeated drone strikes over the past two weeks in Port Sudan have damaged key infrastructure across the crucial Sudanese aid hub, disrupted humanitarian operations, and placed civilians in danger, a UN-appointed human rights expert has warned.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Terror-crime link alarm, child detention in Australia, judiciary in Maldives, Protection of Civilians Week
entry.summary: The head of the UN Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC), called on Monday for renewed global commitment to combating emerging criminal threats and strengthening justice systems worldwide.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN faces deepening financial crisis, urges members to pay up
entry.summary: The United Nations is facing a worsening cash crisis that threatens its ability to carry out vital work, Member States warned this week, as the General Assembly‚Äôs Fifth Committee met to discuss the world body‚Äôs financial health.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Home-bound Syrians find few of the basics needed to survive
entry.summary: Syrians trying to rebuild their lives in their war-torn country urgently need the support of the rest of the world to help them start again, UN aid agencies insist.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World Health Assembly opens amid high-stakes pandemic treaty vote, global funding crisis
entry.summary: The 78th¬†World Health Assembly opened on Monday with a broad appeal to global solidarity, as delegates from around the world gather in Geneva to confront mounting health, climate, and financial challenges ‚Äì and finalise a global treaty to head off the next pandemic.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN relief chief welcomes limited Gaza aid resumption ‚Äì but it‚Äôs a ‚Äòdrop in the ocean‚Äô
entry.summary: The UN humanitarian affairs chief has welcomed Israel‚Äôs decision to allow limited aid to cross into Gaza after 11 weeks of complete blockade ‚Äì but significantly more is needed ‚Äústarting tomorrow morning‚Äù.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: International Criminal Court: Deputies take over amid Prosecutor misconduct probe
entry.summary: The Deputy Prosecutors of the International Criminal Court have assumed leadership of the Office of the Prosecutor following Karim Khan‚Äôs decision to take a leave of absence amid an ongoing UN investigation into allegations of misconduct against him.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Israel ‚Äòapproaches UN‚Äô to resume limited aid deliveries, says aid agency
entry.summary: Amid intensifying Israeli bombing and ground operations in Gaza, the UN‚Äôs relief coordination agency, OCHA, said on Monday that it was in talks with Israel to re-start deliveries of lifesaving supplies to the stricken enclave.

entry.title: GIJN Webinar: Behind the Data ‚Äî Tools and Techniques from the 2025 Sigma Award Winners
entry.summary: In this fast-paced session, winning teams will each have five minutes to share key insights from their reporting process ‚Äî from their favorite tools to innovative methods that helped uncover complex stories. Moderated by journalist and newsroom leader Gina Chua, the session offers a unique, behind-the-scenes look at the workflows powering award-winning journalism.

entry.title: From Flammable Buildings to Slavery‚Äôs Hidden Legacy to Tainted Groundwater: Projects from 10 Countries Win GIJN‚Äôs 2025 Sigma Awards
entry.summary: Ten outstanding data-driven journalism projects, from as many countries, were chosen by a diverse Prize Committee of 17 judges from 498 entries from 80 countries.

entry.title: In Baghdad, Guterres affirms UN will never forget staff killed in Canal Hotel attack
entry.summary: The United Nations will never forget the staff members killed nearly 23 years ago in the attack on its headquarters in Iraq, the Secretary-General said in the capital on Sunday.

entry.summary: Could the world be better prepared for the next pandemic? As nations continue to deal with COVID-19‚Äôs lasting effects, that question is at the heart of an international agreement set to be negotiated in Geneva.

entry.title: Why now's the time to visit underrated Sierra Leone
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The storm is clearing now, though the occasional bolt of lightning illuminates our passage. As my eyes slowly adapt, the world around me reveals itself in flickers and bursts: slender palms bent in prayer over the silent water; the villager to my left clutching a brace of pucker-mouthed catfish; fireflies darting like embers through the gloom.
We‚Äôre bound for Tiwai, a remote river island of 4sq miles situated in one of the last portions of ancient rainforest in West Africa. We set off from Freetown that morning, leaving the capital‚Äôs blue-green shores to follow increasingly non-existent roads east into Sierra Leone‚Äôs Southern Province. It hasn‚Äôt been an easy journey to this point, but with the first stars glimmerin‚Ä¶

entry.title: These coastal activities are on the rise‚Äîhere's how to try them
entry.summary:
‚ÄúGliding from bridge to island and island to bridge, with the Seto Inland Sea stretching endlessly around you, is a truly unforgettable experience,‚Äù says Miho Ogura, co-founder of Hidden Japan Travel. Kayak camping, coasteering and culinary tours ‚Äî experts share six up-and-coming WAYS to experience the world‚Äôs shores.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The coast has always held a magnetic pull. It‚Äôs where we walk for clarity, drawn by the hypnotic crash of waves; where we plunge into saltwater, emerging recharged; and where we linger at sunset, captivated by the endless horizon. Research shows that being near water can lower stress and enhance wellbeing ‚Äî¬†a feeling many travellers are now actively seeking. Fortunately, there‚Äôs no shortage of coa‚Ä¶

entry.title: Where to eat in Vancouver's best food neighborhoods
entry.summary:
Vancouver's best food neighbourhoods offer everything from chic, Chinatown speakeasys to Michelin Guide-recommended small plates. A guide to eating and drinking around the city, from the food counters of Granville Island to the ‚ÄòMichelin mile‚Äô of Mount Pleasant.
This story was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Sandwiched between mountains and Pacific Ocean waves, Vancouver is most often lauded for its phenomenal natural setting, with its skyscrapers brushing up against the old-growth trees of Stanley Park. But the largest city in British Columbia is increasingly becoming known for dining, too, with the Michelin Guide finally awarding the city a constellation of stars in 2022. Each of Vancouver‚Äôs neighbourhoods offers something different ‚Äî the product of immigr‚Ä¶

entry.title: UN humanitarian chief demands resumption of aid in Gaza
entry.summary: Humanitarians demand access to the Gaza Strip and already have a plan in place to deliver life-saving aid to civilians, UN Emergency Relief Coordinator Tom Fletcher said in a strong call issued late on Friday evening.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Civilians killed in drone strike in eastern Ukraine: UN rights monitors
entry.summary: A drone strike in eastern Ukraine on Saturday could possibly be the deadliest in recent weeks, the UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission in the country, HRMMU, has said.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: At Arab League Summit, Guterres reiterates call for Gaza ceasefire
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General renewed his call for a ceasefire in the Gaza Strip and upheld the need for a two-State solution between Israelis and Palestinians in a speech on Saturday to the League of Arab States Summit in Baghdad.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Pandemic accord can be a ‚Äògamechanger‚Äô for marginalised communities, says youth advocate
entry.summary: An international pandemic prevention treaty, three years in the making, is set to be adopted this week in Geneva. Rehman Hassan, a prominent member of the UN World Health Organization (WHO) Youth Council, is confident the accord could make a huge difference to the way that the world reacts to pandemics.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: How did the the Han dynasty bury their royals?
entry.summary:
Rising over the Mancheng district, 120 miles south of Beijing, is Lingshan. More than 2,000 years ago, thousands of tons of rock were removed from its eastern slope to create complex tombs housing the remains of an elite couple: Liu Sheng, prince of Zhongshan, and his wife, Dou Wan.
Miraculously unlooted for the next two millennia, the tombs‚Äô 1960s discovery stunned archaeologists, not only for their engineering but also for the dazzling grave goods they contained. The couple‚Äôs remains were wrapped in jade burial suits now regarded as some of China‚Äôs greatest national treasures.
Liu Sheng‚Äôs father, Jing Di, was the sixth emperor of the Han, the second of China‚Äôs imperial dynasties, which ruled between 206 B.C.and A.D. 220. Beset with rebellions, in 154 B.C., Jing Di sent Liu Sh‚Ä¶

entry.title: Colon cancer is rising in young people. Finally, scientists have a clue about why.
entry.summary:
Colored scanning electron micrograph (SEM) of a macrophage white blood cell (center) that is being destroyed by toxins released by E. coli bacteria (red). Some strains of E. coli release colibactin, a toxin which damages the DNA of cells, and may contribute to the development of colorectal cancer. As scientists question the rise in early colon cancer cases, a new study is offering some potential answers.
Colorectal cancer should be on your radar: Today, one in five people under the age of 54 is diagnosed with the disease, marking an 11 percent uptick in this age group over the past two decades. What, exactly, is fueling the surge in younger patients has perplexed scientists and medical professionals alike.
(Colon cancer is rising among young adults. Here are signs to watch for‚Ä¶

entry.title: Ancient Greeks and Romans were obsessed with diet advice, too
entry.summary:
Ancient Roman still-life mosaic fish and vegetables, 2nd century, from a villa at Tor Marancia. Vatican Museums, Rome From protein-filled meals to the benefits of lentils and intermittent fasting, the Classical world had strong opinions about how to stay healthy.
Before Instagram trends and DNA-based diets, Greek and Roman physicians used diet as the primary form of healthcare. Shockingly, their advice seems both modern and remarkably sensible. Too much red meat (specifically beef) could lead to cancer, wrote the second century-CE Roman medic Galen. Those who were looking to lose weight, wrote Hippocrates, should try what we call fasting cardio: exercising on an empty stomach before eating. And chicken soup, wrote Dioscorides, the father of pharmacology, ‚Äúis very often given to tho‚Ä¶

entry.title: Got food poisoning? One of these 4 bugs is likely the cause
entry.summary:
A color enhanced transmission electron micrograph shows a listeria bacterium in tissue. This pathogen is the third-leading cause of death from foodborne illness in the United States. Infections are typically linked to unpasteurized raw milk, hot dogs, dry sausages, smoked seafood, and salads, to name a few.  Listeria. E. Coli. Salmonella. Norovirus. Here's what to know about these common culprits of foodborne illness‚Äîand how to keep them from spreading.
As temperatures continue to rise, so too does the risk of food poisoning.¬†
U.S. officials are currently investigating an upsurge of listeria cases linked to ready-to-eat foods such as sandwiches and protein snacks.
About 48 million people in the U.S.(about one in six) fall prey to a foodborne pathogen every year, acco‚Ä¶

entry.title: Avoid the crowds at U.S. national parks‚Äîby going underwater
entry.summary:
The underwater kelp forests at Anacapa Island in Channel Islands National Park. From sunken ships to kelp forests to vibrant reefs, these national park experiences are as uncrowded as it gets. Here‚Äôs where to go.
You might know the phrase ‚Äúhalf the park is after dark,‚Äù a National Park Service campaign designed to spread out visitors and encourage them to explore in new ways. But to avoid the crowds in the country‚Äôs most beloved places, going out under the moonlight isn‚Äôt the only option for seclusion‚Äîyou can go underwater.
And it‚Äôs not just the nation‚Äôs coastal parks that offer watery worlds to explore. From the bubbles of Yellowstone to the shipwrecks of Isle Royale, the parks below offer uncommon, unparalleled experiences‚Äîwhere the only crowds come with fins, flippers, and g‚Ä¶

entry.title: Regenerated organs are tantalizingly close
entry.summary:
Stem cells (like the ones above, growing in petri dishes) are able to differentiate into any type of cell in the body, including cells that generate and repair tissue that's been damaged by disease. After decades of hype and setbacks, scientists have made impressive progress into tricking stem cells into repairing organs.
In the 1986 movie Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home, Dr. McCoy hands a dialysis patient a single pill and she immediately grows a new kidney. That‚Äôs the holy grail of regenerative medicine, and it has proven frustratingly elusive.
When disease damages crucial organs like the heart or lungs, the best doctors can generally do is stop the harm from worsening. Now, after three decades of trial and error, the prospect of revving up the body‚Äôs own stem cells to become ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Where to taste Greece‚Äôs best olive oil
entry.summary:
According to Greek mythology, Athena planted the first olive tree on the Acropolis. From tastings with olive oil sommeliers to celebrating harvest season at family-run mills, here‚Äôs how to experience oleotourism and immerse yourself in the world of Greece‚Äôs ‚Äúliquid gold.‚Äù
The silvery-green olive trees that blanket Greece are as rooted in its culture as the stars and sea. According to Greek mythology, Athena planted the first olive tree on the Acropolis, triumphing over Poseidon to become Athens‚Äô patron goddess‚Äîforever cementing the evergreen as a sacred symbol of prosperity. In ancient Greece, Olympic victors were crowned with olive branches, while Homer referred to the antioxidant-rich juice as ‚Äúliquid gold‚Äù in his epic poems. Today, Greece remains one of the world‚Äôs top olive oil‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to spend two days in Tofino on Vancouver Island
entry.summary:
Tofino Harbour is the gateway to Clayoquot Sound's 60-mile-wide stretch of water, home to Tofino‚Äôs islands and inlets. Windswept surfing beaches, rainforest hikes and seaweed spas are all on offer at this bohemian outpost on Vancouver Island.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Set on Vancouver Island‚Äôs wild western shore, Tofino is a town surrounded by windswept beaches and coastal rainforest. It has a hippy air and is home to year-round surfers, Indigenous artists and an increasing number of chefs, drawn to the natural riches of the Pacific coast. Come for ocean waves, stay for the fish tacos and star-spangled evenings.
8am: Breakfast at the beach Start the day at Cox Bay, a mile-long stretch of sand just south of Tofino. The Beach Shack‚Ä¶

entry.title: Can humans smell insects? The truth about the viral debate
entry.summary:
Ladybugs lay down "trails" of scents to help guide other ladybugs to a meetup spot. People on TikTok are arguing about it, so we asked the experts to weigh in.
It‚Äôs an ongoing debate on¬†TikTok: A couple wonders why one of them can smell ladybugs and the other can‚Äôt.¬†
Below that video, one commenter notes that ants smell, too, like a ‚Äúcombo of tomato vine and dirt.‚Äù¬†
Another commenter¬†says the ant smell is more like ‚Äúblue cheese or pen ink.‚Äù¬†¬†
And one less fortunate¬†commenter notes: ‚ÄúI can smell roaches. It‚Äôs the worst superpower I have ever developed.‚Äù¬†
Just like ‚Äúthe dress‚Äù divided the internet a decade ago, the insect smell question is one of the latest debates.¬†
So, why do some people pick up these odors, while others don‚Äôt? The answer goes back to how‚Ä¶

entry.title: Pandemic heroes stepped up in 2020 ‚Äì now they‚Äôre asking world leaders to do the same
entry.summary: As world leaders negotiate the landmark Pandemic Preparedness Treaty at the WHO Assembly, we revisit frontline doctors, community advocates, a youth volunteer, and a journalist who lived through the storm of COVID-19. Theirs are just some of the millions of testimonies worldwide helping shape the urgent call for action.

entry.summary: In July 2024, famine was detected in the Sudan‚Äôs Zamzam IDP camp. In the following months, the official alert expanded to other camps in Darfur and Western Nuba Mountains. From December until now, famine has been¬†confirmed in five other areas of the war-torn country. A further 17 areas are at risk.
