entry.title: We could still save the world‚Äôs most adorable dolphin
entry.summary:
An orphaned Irrawaddy dolphin rests in the arms of its caretaker at the Marine Endangered Species Veterinary Hospital in Rayong, Thailand. Irrawaddy dolphins have captured hearts for generations for their adorable smirks and ability to help humans catch fish. Now it's our turn to help them.
On Myanmar‚Äôs Ayeyarwady River, fishers tap the side of their boats and wait. If they‚Äôre lucky, a gray dolphin with a rounded head and smirk appears. These are Irrawaddy dolphins‚Äîsocial, intelligent mammals that have fished alongside humans for generations. The dolphins herd fish toward the fishers‚Äô cast nets, and in return, they snag fish trapped near the edges or stuck in the mud at the bottom for themselves.¬†
One dolphin, named Gotama, is even known for giving a special signal‚Äîa flic‚Ä¶

entry.title: You can‚Äôt tell the story of New Orleans without its Black Catholics
entry.summary: A member of the Treme Brass Band plays during a concert marking the anniversary of Hurricane Katrina Concert at the historically black St. Augustine Catholic Church in New Orleans, Louisiana. Founded in 1841, St. Augustine is the oldest Black parish in the United States and was the place of worship for some of the city's most influential historical figures. The revelation that Pope Leo XIV has Louisiana Creole roots shines a light on a community of Catholics that has shaped New Orleans, from a famous Voodoo priestess to the self-proclaimed inventor of jazz. The election of Pope Leo XIV as the first American pontiff‚Äîand the subsequent revelation that he has Louisiana Creole roots‚Äîshines new light on a city‚Ä¶

entry.title: Married by When
entry.summary: Because everyone who is 30 years and older loves getting asked when they're going to settle down and get married. Tags: age, demographics, marriage

entry.title: This ancient port in England is having a 21st-century renaissance
entry.summary:
Hastings is popular in the spring and summer, when the sunlit sea is turquoise, the seafront rides are in full swing and the entire town heads out for Jack in the Green ‚Äî a day of folk dancing, parades and merriment held on May Day. Tradition and innovation combine in this historic port town on the East Sussex coast in southern England.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Mention Hastings and people still refer to the battle of 1066, which is a shame given the town has changed so much ‚Äî since the 11th century, certainly, but over the past decade, too. Like many British seaside resorts, Hastings and its neighbour, St Leonards-on-Sea, had their heyday in the Victorian era before falling into a period of decline. Their revivals in recent years have‚Ä¶

entry.title: Can food bring people together? Stanley Tucci thinks so.
entry.summary: Stanley Tucci, host of the new series Tucci in Italy, ventures beyond Rome to Lazio's less-visited countryside to understand the relationship between the ancient metropolis and rural heartland. From a pine-needle pesto in Trentino-Aldo Adige to a Roman pizza in Lazio, the host of Tucci in Italy tells us about the dishes and people that define some of Italy‚Äôs most distinct regions. Stanley Tucci‚Äôs new series has been 20 years in the making ‚Äî or at least, that‚Äôs how long it‚Äôs been since the idea first struck him. His mission? To ignite curiosity, not only about Italy, but the ways in which we can explore the world through food.¬†Tucci in Italy, which premieres May 18 on National Geographic, follows the acclaimed actor and author as he navigates the culinary tra‚Ä¶

entry.title: A practical guide to exploring the Alps' classic highlights
entry.summary:
Roads in the Alps are generally well maintained and signposted, but you‚Äôll need to be a confident driver to tackle inclines and hairpin bends. These mountains have long been winter favourites, and they‚Äôre now becoming increasingly popular in the summer, too. Here‚Äôs what to keep in mind when planning a warm-weather visit.  
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Wild as they are, the Alps are brilliantly accessible in the warmer months, whether you want to devise your own multi-day, cross-country trip on the frequent, efficient trains, or hit the trail on a long-distance, hut-to-hut hike. For planning, booking and money-saving tips, try this handy guide.
Pack for the outdoors. Bring layers: a breathable fleece, loose walking trousers, hik‚Ä¶

entry.title: ‚ÄòWe are still waiting for our loved ones‚Äô: Families of the abducted speak out
entry.summary: Two families ‚Äì one still waiting for answers 75 years after a father was taken during the Korean War, the other pleading for a son‚Äôs return from captivity in Gaza ‚Äì shared their testimonies before the UN Security Council on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: New displacement orders force thousands to flee as famine looms
entry.summary: Intensified hostilities continue in the Gaza Strip, bringing further death, displacement and destruction as the weeks-long aid blockade grinds on, the UN humanitarian affairs office (OCHA) said on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudden escalation of trade tensions sends shockwaves through global economy
entry.summary: Amid escalating trade tensions and growing policy uncertainties, the global economy stands at a fragile turning point, according to a new report on Thursday from the UN Department of Economic and Social Affairs (UN DESA).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN needed ‚Äòmore than ever before‚Äô says Germany‚Äôs candidate to head General Assembly
entry.summary: The former Foreign Minister of Germany outlined her vision for the role of UN General Assembly President, pledging to make the world body more effective, inclusive and focused on results.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Over 60 per cent of the Arab world still outside the banking system
entry.summary: Between 2016 and 2024, the number of Egyptians with a bank account ‚Äì which experts say is essential for financial inclusion - tripled, from 17.1 million to over 51 million.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Libya‚Äôs fragile peace tested again as new clashes roil Tripoli
entry.summary: A fragile calm has settled over Tripoli after a sudden surge of violence this week left parts of the city in ruins, claimed civilian lives, and heightened concerns about the stability of Libya‚Äôs already fragile political and security situation.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòThe world is failing its health checkup,‚Äô says WHO
entry.summary: In just two years, between 2019 and 2021, life expectancy worldwide fell by 1.8 years ‚Äì the largest fall in recent history according to the World Health Organization (WHO), in the shadow of the COVID-19 pandemic.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Listening to birds sing really does soothe your brain. Here‚Äôs why.
entry.summary: A European robin, Erithacus rubecula, sings in a tree in Norfolk, England. Studies have linked the sound of birdsong to reduced levels of depression and anxiety. Spending time in nature is important for your mental health. But studies show that even just listening to birds singing can ease symptoms of anxiety and depression. Each spring, as billions of birds head north during peak migration, their melodic songs become impossible to drown out‚Äînot that you would want to. Their ‚Äúdawn chorus‚Äù signals that brighter, warmer days are finally here. It‚Äôs also a scientifically proven balm for your brain. Scientists know that nature is a salve for the soul. Getting outdoors keeps your body active. Spending time in the forest lowers your stress, heart rate, and blood pressure. Gazi‚Ä¶

entry.title: The real-life rise and fall of Griselda Blanco
entry.summary:
Griselda Blanco is suspected of being involved in 40 murders across the U.S., including all three of her husbands. At its height, her network was pushing $80 million a month in cocaine. How did a girl who grew up in poverty in Colombia become an international narcotics queenpin pushing $80 million a month in cocaine?
The Godmother. The Black Widow. Queenpin. Griselda Blanco‚Äôs many aliases and nicknames speak to the notoriety she gained by heading a billion-dollar, blood-soaked drug empire that stretched from Colombia to the United States.
The subject of the Netflix‚Äôs Emmy nominated series¬†Griselda, Blanco‚Äôs life blurred the line between fact and fiction as she clawed her way to a position of power¬†in a violent world. So, who was the real woman behind the myth?
Blanco wa‚Ä¶

entry.title: Mark Synnott isn't afraid to be reckless
entry.summary: Writer Mark Synnott‚Äôs ship, Polar Sun, navigates the northwest passage during a 2022 attempt to retrace the steps of famed British Explorer John Franklin. The adventurer and author of Into the Ice recounts his harrowing attempt to sail the Northwest Passage and why he always listens to his gut. In 2022, Mark Synnott set sail from his home in Maine to complete the Northwest Passage, the legendary route through the Arctic that connects the Atlantic and Pacific. Synnott wanted to retrace the path of an 1845 expedition led by British explorer Sir John Franklin, who was attempting to chart the sea route over North America and open a valuable trade avenue with East Asia. But along the way Franklin‚Äôs two ships, Erebus and Terror, became trapped in the ice, stranding the exp‚Ä¶

entry.title: Passports Are Key to Uncovering Offshore Secrecy ‚Äî We Use Machine Learning to Find Them Efficiently
entry.summary: Passports can help unlock secret ownership of offshore companies, but finding them is often challenging. At ICIJ, we decided to build a new detection tool to speed up this process.

entry.title: Video: How common are spiritual beliefs in the U.S.?
entry.summary: In this video, we dive into the impact spirituality has on Americans and how it overlaps with and differs from religiousness. The post Video: How common are spiritual beliefs in the U.S.? appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: How changing the way you breathe can improve your brain and body
entry.summary:
If you‚Äôve ever been told to ‚Äútake a deep breath‚Äù during a stressful moment, know that this advice isn‚Äôt merely a platitude‚Äîit‚Äôs backed by science.
Research shows conscious breathing comes with a host of immediate and long-term benefits that include improved heart health, reduced anxiety, boosted mood, improved cognitive function, and better sleep quality.
‚ÄúBreathwork is one of the simplest and profoundly effective tools we have for calming the nervous system and boosting physical and mental resilience,‚Äù says Guy Fincham, founder of the breathwork lab at Brighton & Sussex Medical School in England and co-author of¬†breathwork research.¬†‚ÄúAnd yet, precisely because it‚Äôs so accessible, its power is often underestimated.‚Äù¬†
Here‚Äôs why mindful inhaling and exhaling can be so good fo‚Ä¶

entry.title: Dogs. Bedbugs. Corn. They all have this one thing in common.
entry.summary:
Scientists are trying to define the situationship between domestic animals and humans. Under a new definition, populations of dogs and bedbugs are in, while horses and pigs are out.  You might think you know which animals and plants are considered "domesticated" or ‚Äúdomestic‚Äù and which ones aren't‚Äîbut a new definition has launched a big debate among scientists.
Your pet pug is without a doubt a domestic dog. A cow on a farm seems domestic, too. But what about an indoor/outdoor cat, that brings home unwelcome gifts? What about animals that live in our homes to our chagrin, like a rat or a bedbug?
Even among scientists, there is no universally agreed upon definition of what domestication looks like or what makes an animal ‚Äúdomestic.‚Äù Elinor Karlsson and Kathryn Lord faced t‚Ä¶

entry.title: What Is News?
entry.summary: As people are exposed to more information from more sources than ever before, how they define and feel about ‚Äúnews‚Äù has become less clear-cut. The post What Is News? appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: This Pew Research Center study uses a multimethod approach to understanding what ‚Äúnews‚Äù means to Americans today. The project includes three different types of research methodologies: a qualitative online discussion board with 57 U.S. adults, a nationally representative survey of 9,482 U.S. adults conducted through Pew Research Center‚Äôs American Trends Panel (ATP), and on-the-record, in-depth [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Remember the Ice Bucket Challenge? It‚Äôs back.
entry.summary:
People participate in the "Ice Bucket Challenge" in Gloucester, MA during the last annual "Plunge 4 Pete" on Dec. 28, 2019, what would have been Pete Frates' 35th birthday. The fundraiser started in 2012 after Frates' diagnosis of ALS, and eventually helped popularize the Ice Bucket Challenge. The 2014 social media trend put the spotlight on unanswered questions and needed treatments for ALS. Will its return help? We asked the father of one of the original Ice Bucket Challenge founders.
More than a decade after the viral trend first got its start, thousands of people are dusting off their buckets and dumping ice water on their heads all over again‚Äîbut this time, for mental health.
The viral 2014 Ice Bucket Challenge raised $115 million in six weeks for what was, at the time, a‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why Panama City's appeal goes far beyond its namesake canal
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
At first glance, Panama City is all flashy skyline, its slew of sparkling high-rises towering above the waters of the bay like a cartoon vision of a futuristic metropolis. But the so-called ‚ÄòMiami of Central America‚Äô has a hidden history ‚Äî one that extends far beyond the canal that first put it on most travellers‚Äô mental map.
Panama is effectively a borderland between Central and South America, and its famous canal ‚Äî built in the early 1900s ‚Äî slices the country in two. This 51-mile waterway is a giant shortcut, connecting the Pacific and Atlantic oceans, sparing sea travellers an 8,000-mile voyage around the continent‚Äôs southern tip. Each year, billions of dollars‚Äô worth of cargo travel along it, and the comings a‚Ä¶

entry.title: The real science of brain rot
entry.summary:
In 2024, the Oxford University Press declared ‚Äúbrain rot‚Äù the word of the year. If Ohio is just a midwestern state to you and mewwing is something your cat does, you might not be as familiar with the term as those who have adopted the Gen Z and Alpha lexicons that popularized it. Still, you‚Äôve probably encountered its effects.
‚ÄúBrain rot‚Äù describes the supposed mental decline resulting from too much time spent in the chasms of the digital world reserved for trivial content. But, while endless hours scrolling on TikTok may prompt a headache, strained eyes, and the latest trending sound to loop in your head, ‚Äúyour brain doesn‚Äôt literally rot until after death,‚Äù says Andy McKenzie, a neuroscientist who studies functional brain preservation at the nonprofit Apex Neuroscience in Oregon. entry.title: Why there's a 10,000-person wait list to scavenge London‚Äôs Thames
entry.summary:
ON A SUMMER DAY in central London, a 44-year-old woman named Lucy Peel descended a slippery stairway on the bank of the River Thames to crouch on her hands and knees over a particularly intriguing pile of mud. It was low tide, and the waters of the river had receded substantially. Ignoring the obvious tangles of trash‚Äîplastic bags, vape pens, broken glass‚ÄîPeel painstakingly scanned the exposed riverbed until she spotted something nestled in the sand that could easily be mistaken for a leaf. After carefully prying it loose, she held up a wafer-thin ceramic shard and had a familiar feeling that she was holding a piece of ancient history.
Later, an archaeologist would confirm her suspicion: It was a fragment of Roman pottery. ‚ÄúEven though it‚Äôs so fine, somehow it‚Äôs still survived 2,000 y‚Ä¶

entry.title: UK's 'restaurants with rooms' offer a gourmet meal and a stay
entry.summary:
The Pig near Bath, in the Mendip Hills, has an extensive kitchen garden, with beds of greens, roots, herbs and fruit ‚Äî as well as a mushroom-growing shed. These gourmet getaways offer world-class cuisine and stylish bedrooms, all under one roof.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
A meal at a great destination restaurant is the ideal activity around which to plan a trip ‚Äî and what better way to extend the experience than by checking in overnight and doing it all again at breakfast the next day? Restaurants with rooms, where you come for the food and stay for the, well, stay can be found all over the UK. Here are some of our favourites, from a former pub in Yorkshire to a castle in the Scottish Highlands.

entry.title: ‚ÄòStop the 21st century atrocity‚Äô in Gaza, Fletcher urges UN Security Council
entry.summary: No aid has entered Gaza for more than 10 weeks and every single one of the 2.1 million people there faces famine conditions, the UN Emergency Relief Coordinator Tom Fletcher said on Tuesday in a briefing to the Security Council in New York.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Half of women‚Äôs organizations in crisis zones risk closure within six months
entry.summary: Women‚Äôs organisations operating in crisis settings are being pushed to the brink by widespread funding cuts. In a report published on Tuesday, UN Women ‚Äì the UN agency for gender equality ‚Äì warned that 47 per cent of these groups may be forced to close within the next six months.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: GAZA LIVE: 'Humanity, the law and reason must prevail' in Gaza, UN relief chief tells Security Council
entry.summary: The Security Council is meeting in New York to discuss the horror of Gaza, where humanitarians warn of ‚Äúa critical risk of famine‚Äù and aid shipments have been blocked by Israel for over 70 days. UN relief chief Tom Fletcher briefed the Security Council, asking ambassadors if they will act decisively "to prevent genocide" and ensure respect for international law. He also called on Hamas to release all hostages and stop putting civilians at risk. Follow live for key updates from UN Headquarters and reports from the region. App users can follow coverage here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: US deportations raise serious human rights concerns
entry.summary: The UN Human Rights High Commissioner Volker T√ºrk has voiced concern over the recent deportation of large numbers of non-nationals from the United States, particularly to third countries.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Number of internally displaced breaks new record with no let-up in conflicts, disasters
entry.summary: A record 83.4 million people have been forced from their homes around the world, fuelled by an increase in disasters and conflict, the UN migration agency, IOM, said on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: As funding cuts bite, UN chief announces new dawn for peacekeeping
entry.summary: The future of peacekeeping took centre stage on Tuesday in Berlin as UN chief Ant√≥nio Guterres urged Member States to do more to support the global body‚Äôs 'blue helmets' and stave off the worst impacts of deep funding cuts.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: 57 children reported dead from malnutrition, says WHO
entry.summary: In the aid desert of Gaza, malnourished children are dying while survivors can now expect a lifetime of dire health problems, the UN World Health Organization (WHO) said on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN aviation council finds Russia responsible for downing of Malaysian Airlines flight
entry.summary: A UN body has found that Russia was responsible for the 17 July 2014 downing of Malaysian Airlines flight MH17 over eastern Ukraine that killed all 298 people on board.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Tariff timeline with China, so far
entry.summary: The U.S. and China put a semi-hold on tariffs for the next 90‚Ä¶ Tags: China, New York Times, tariff

entry.title: English wine is on the rise. Here is where to experience it
entry.summary:
Domaine Evremond, established by Taittinger, produces Chardonnay, Pinot Noir and Pinot Meunier vines on its south-facing slopes in Kent. Savour the best of English wine with new festivals and vineyard experiences.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
There was a time, not so long ago really, when English oenophiles looking to set up shop had no choice but to relocate to the balmier climes of France or Italy. Not anymore. A changing climate, a culture of experimentation and greater awareness of which regions are best suited to grape growing have combined to make England one of Europe‚Äôs most exciting viticultural destinations ‚Äî and it shows. Across the country, you‚Äôll find tours and tastings that showcase some of England‚Äôs best homegrown producers. ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Alcohol is killing more women than ever before
entry.summary:
Jasmine Charbonier‚Äôs heavy drinking started in college. By her early 30s, she was downing up to eight tequila cocktails daily, several days each week. A few years ago she tried to quit and was surprised when she plummeted into withdrawal.
Research shows that while men are still more likely to die from an alcohol-related disease, the gap is narrowing. The most recent figures, published in 2024, found deaths in women have risen at a rate of 35 percent, while men increased just 27 percent.
(8 things we've learned about how alcohol harms the body.)
The rise in deaths results from an unfortunate gender equality: Women now raise their glass almost as frequently as men. A recent U.S. government survey found 45 percent of women drank in the prior month, compared to 50 percent of men‚Ä¶

entry.title: The secret program that brought Nazi scientists to the U.S.
entry.summary:
On July 20, 1969, a crew of American astronauts successfully landed on the moon for the first time. Though only three of them were in the spacecraft, thousands of people had contributed their brainpower to put the astronauts in flight.
Among the contributors: German scientists who had been members of the Nazi Party. The United States recruited them in the years after World War II¬†under a federal program called Operation Paperclip.¬†
The program remains a controversial chapter in American history, when U.S. officials incorporated former Nazis into American life and institutions. Here‚Äôs how Operation Paperclip got off the ground.
In the spring of 1945, Allied forces were closing in on Nazi Germany, and the end of the war in Europe was in sight. Officials started to make p‚Ä¶

entry.title: 8 ways to find calm in Thailand's larger-than-life capital city
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Bangkok may have a reputation as one of the world‚Äôs biggest concrete jungles, but in between the neon-lit streets, rooftop bars and crowded markets there are some glorious pockets of calm. The city‚Äôs network of canals help create breathing space among the tuk-tuk packed neighbourhoods, and there‚Äôs a surprising amount of green space in the city‚Äôs environs ‚Äî accessible by boat, bike or on foot. Here are eight of our favourite hideaways.¬†
One of several plush hotels lining the Chao Phraya River, the Riva Arun is noteworthy for its peaceful, top-floor terrace restaurant, Above Riva. You can ease into the day with breakfast or settle in for sunset cocktails, watching boats crisscross the river. The dinner menu goes b‚Ä¶

The APIÔºå which has evolved through five preview iterationsÔºå aims to simplify and provide developers with clearerÔºå safer frameworks for managing parallel tasksÔºå particularly when working with virtual threads. Developers now open a scope through static factory methodsÔºå such as `StructuredTaskScope.open()`Ôºå a change that clarifies defaults and paves the way for richer completion policies. Each fork launches a subtaskÔºå by default on a virtual threadÔºå returning a `Subtask` handle whose `get()` is safe only after `join()` completes. üìä ÊñáÁ´†‰ø°ÊÅØ

entry.title: Traveling during hurricane season? Here's what you should know
entry.summary:
Tropical cyclones are unpredictable so being prepared and knowing your options in case of a storm are key when travelling during hurricane season. From what to pack to whether travel insurance will cover you, here‚Äôs what you need to know about travelling during tropical cyclones.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
Long balmy days, sparkling turquoise waters ‚Äî these are the classic ingredients of a tropical break. But risk going during the hurricane season and you could end up looking at a very different picture. It doesn‚Äôt necessarily mean trips have to be off the agenda though. In fact, for some, off-season prices and the lack of crowds make hurricane season a particularly attractive time to travel. Here‚Äôs how best to prepare.
Collective‚Ä¶

entry.title: Join a homegrown family feast in Italy's Basilicata region
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Deft and swift, she forms millimetre-thick sheets, slicing them into ribbons that she wraps around her narrow rolling pin to shape the screw-like ss√´ppondap√≤rt√´ (the word for ‚Äòdoor hinge pin‚Äô in local dialect) or cuts into the roughly square-shaped takk√´nu√®dd√´. Next, the remaining dough ‚Äî an egg-free mix of semolina flour and 00 pasta flour ‚Äî is divided and rolled into thin sausages. She cuts these into one- and two-finger-width pieces and presses them into cavatelli and orecchiette, her digits moving in a blur of speed. Maria Coppola Colucci has been working in the kitchen at this pace for two hours and the septuagenarian grandmother shows no sign of flagging.
‚ÄúWe were in the garden first thing this morning diggin‚Ä¶

entry.title: Field of Dreams: Football Breathes Life into Yemen‚Äôs Camps
entry.summary: Every summer in Ma‚Äôrib, Yemen, a place marked by loss and uncertainty, a football tournament offers a rare kind of hope. For hundreds of displaced youth living across more than a dozen sites, it‚Äôs a chance to unite, to belong, and to dream.

entry.title: Try this budget alternative to Canada's famous Rocky Mountaineer
entry.summary:
Completed in 1914 as the western end of the Grand Trunk Pacific Railway, the Skeena travels through some of British Columbia‚Äôs wildest backcountry, including the 24,700sq mile Great Bear Rainforest, the largest temperate forest on Earth. Crossing vast tracts of British Columbian wilderness, the Skeena is one of Canada‚Äôs most thrilling, and little-known, rail journeys.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
‚ÄúLadies and gentlemen, we‚Äôll be making an unscheduled stop here to pick up another passenger,‚Äù announces train manager Alain Vermette. ‚ÄúIn fact, we need to back up. We just missed his stop.‚Äù
Brakes squeal and gears grind as Via Rail Line 6 ‚Äî better known as ‚Äòthe Skeena‚Äô ‚Äî slows, shifts into reverse and trundles back down the track. A minute l‚Ä¶

entry.title: Where to see wildlife in Europe this summer
entry.summary:
Summer is the best time for wildlife-watching in Europe and spotting animals such as bears, wolves and lynx, is made possible thanks to knowledgable guides and various animal reintroduction schemes. From the FƒÉgƒÉra»ô Mountains of Romania to the teeming sea cliffs of St Kilda in Scotland, Europe is still home to staggering displays of summer wildlife. Whether you‚Äôre searching for sperm whales, brown bears, dolphins or wolves, here are six of the best destinations to target.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
Although quite densely populated, Europe isn‚Äôt short of lonely island outposts, remote mountain ranges and dark, seemingly impenetrable forests ‚Äî and many of them shelter world-class displays of animal activity. You‚Äôll need to be well-equipped‚Ä¶

entry.title: Whatever happened to the samurai?
entry.summary:
The samurai, Japan‚Äôs celebrated lineage of warriors, emerged in the Heian period (794-1185), when the rise of their status enabled them to mingle with the refined nobility living in the then-capital of Heian-ky≈ç (Kyoto). Samurai fought in the ≈ånin War and during the period of unrest that followed. From then on, the bushi, as the samurai were also called, made their mark on Japanese history with their exceptional fighting prowess, becoming emblematic of Japanese culture.
The high point of samurai history is often associated with the Tokugawa shogunate, also known as the Edo period (1603‚Äì1868), a time of peace, prosperity, isolationist policies, and cultural growth. This is the most studied era of Japanese history and the period in which novelists, filmmakers, and comic book creators te‚Ä¶

entry.title: This is the longest hiking trail in Central Asia
entry.summary:
Tourists prepare for a boating adventure on K√∂l-Suu (or Kel-Suu), a lake located in the heart of the Tian Shan mountain range in Kyrgyzstan. By summer's end, more than 600 miles will be added to the Kyrgyz Nomad Trail, granting hikers access to lesser-known parts of the country.
Adventurous hikers now have access to see a different side of Kyrgyzstan. The¬†Kyrgyz Nomad Trail¬†(KNT) is a 1,243-mile (2,000-kilometer) long-distance hiking trail in northern and eastern Kyrgyzstan, which make it the longest trail network in Central Asia. Launched in June 2024, the KNT‚Äîa network of 18 marked sections‚Äîruns west to east passing through states (oblasts) such as Jalal-Abad, Naryn, and Issyk-Kul.
Along the trail, hikers also experience¬†the beauty of Kyrgyzstan¬†firsthand with natural landma‚Ä¶

entry.title: Do chimpanzees have rhythm? Listen to their drumming.
entry.summary:
Chimpanzees drum and make calls to communicate. Two new studies have found they drum to send message across large distances and can create complex vocalizations. New research on the rhythmic drumming and complex calls of chimpanzees could point scientists to the origins of language.
‚ÄúYou feel it in your body when they drum‚Äîit‚Äôs insanely impressive,‚Äù says Vesta Eleuteri.¬†
She‚Äôs a cognitive biologist at the University of Vienna who studies chimpanzee drumming and observed over 350 drumming performances like this in five African countries.
Chimpanzees in West Africa hold onto trees with their hands while kicking against roots with their feet, emitting powerful sounds that travel long distances, sometimes over a half mile.¬†
‚ÄúThey‚Äôre so fast sometimes‚Ä¶ their hands and fee‚Ä¶

entry.title: This tree's destruction prompted outrage‚Äîand now a guilty verdict
entry.summary:
The Sycamore Gap tree grew in the dip of an ancient Roman wall. A lone tree growing along an ancient Roman wall was a beloved fixture in the landscape. Why did the Sycamore Gap tree‚Äôs illegal felling spark so much emotion?
In the early hours of September 28, 2023, an act of violence and vandalism shocked the U.K.
The next day, news of the attack dominated social media and mainstream news coverage, leading to outpourings of grief, fury at its senselessness, and pilgrimages to the remote stretch of countryside where the crime took place.

entry.title: This Alaska volcano might erupt soon
entry.summary:
For the last year, Alaska's Mount Spurr has been showing signs of a potential eruption on the horizon. If an eruption happens, it would likely occur at Crater Peak, shown in the background of this summit photograph.  An explosion on Mount Spurr could generate massive cloud of ash, which could mess with airplanes and cause issues for humans.
Over the past 12 months, an Alaskan volcano named Mount Spurr has become noticeably agitated: It‚Äôs been swelling, quaking, and venting noxious gases. As it stands today, the evidence could point to a major explosive event on the horizon‚Äîor the mountain might just be harmlessly blowing off some steam.

entry.title: Why do so many animals ‚Äòglow‚Äô in UV light?
entry.summary:
Scorpions are one of many animals that appear to glow under ultraviolet (UV) light. Scientists are finding that photoluminescence is more common than previously suspected.  Animals with ultraviolet color patterns can be found all over nature. Here‚Äôs what we know about what purpose these patterns serve.
Shine an ultraviolet flashlight on flying squirrels, and they glow bright pink. Catch a scorpion on a full moon, and you‚Äôll notice that it‚Äôs a haunting blue. Rays and sharks can turn neon green, while nearby coral come alive in electric reds.
And hawksbill sea turtles? Under ultraviolet light, they turn into glow-in-the-dark, underwater Christmas decorations, with both greens and reds arranged in overlapping chevrons.¬†

entry.title: Sharing meals could be the key to better mental health
entry.summary:
The cuisines across the Mediterranean, Latin American, and Southeast Asian may vary, but the practice of sharing food and gathering around the table is so deeply rooted in these cultures that it‚Äôs almost sacred. Meals are eaten together, plates are passed with intention, and no one rises until all are finished.
But in other parts of the world, communal dining has become a rarity. The idea of taking a full hour for lunch is met with skepticism, and even basic rituals like sharing a proper meal are brushed aside as indulgent. How has something so essential to our well-being become so easily dismissed?
According to the 2025 World Happiness Report, meal sharing ranks among the strongest predictors of well-being, comparable to factors like income and employment.
